skill.name: solid-principles
skill.description: SOLID principles adapted for functional and TypeScript-first development.
skill.summary: SOLID principles adapted for functional and TypeScript-first development.
skill.author: DoubleslashSE

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation/educational skill containing only markdown explanations and TypeScript code examples demonstrating SOLID design principles. The static scanner misidentified TypeScript template literals as shell backticks, arithmetic operations as cryptographic algorithms, and code comments as system reconnaissance. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or environment variable access exists. Verified by reading SKILL.md (282 lines) and examples.md (387 lines) which contain only educational content.

content.user_title: Apply SOLID Principles to TypeScript Code
content.value_statement: SOLID principles help you write maintainable software. This skill teaches you to build testable, extensible TypeScript applications that adapt to changing requirements.
actual_capabilities: Explains Single Responsibility Principle with practical examples
Demonstrates Open/Closed Principle for extensible code
Shows Liskov Substitution for proper inheritance design
Teaches Interface Segregation with focused abstractions
Illustrates Dependency Inversion with dependency injection
limitations: Educational content, does not automatically refactor code
Examples are in TypeScript, may not apply directly to other languages
Does not analyze existing codebases for violations

use_cases.title: Learn SOLID fundamentals
use_cases.description: Understand each principle through practical TypeScript examples and common violations

use_cases.title: Review design decisions
use_cases.description: Validate design choices and identify refactoring opportunities in legacy code

use_cases.title: Study design patterns
use_cases.description: Learn how SOLID principles guide object-oriented and functional design decisions

prompt_templates.title: Identify violations
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this TypeScript class and identify which SOLID principles it violates. Explain each violation and suggest a refactoring approach.

prompt_templates.title: Apply Single Responsibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this class to follow the Single Responsibility Principle. Extract separate functions for each responsibility.

prompt_templates.title: Design extensible systems
prompt_templates.prompt: Redesign this switch statement to follow the Open/Closed Principle using strategy pattern or composition.

prompt_templates.title: Implement dependency inversion
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this service to depend on abstractions instead of concrete implementations. Show the interface design.

output_examples.input: My OrderService class handles validation, business logic, database access, and notifications. How can I improve it?
output: Single Responsibility Violation detected: 4 distinct responsibilities
Extract validation logic into a dedicated OrderValidator function
Move database operations to a separate OrderRepository
Create an EmailNotifier interface for notifications
Inject all dependencies for testability and flexibility

output_examples.input: I have many if-else statements checking discount types. How do I make this extensible?
output: Open/Closed Principle violation: modifying existing code to add new types
Create a DiscountStrategy type for discount calculations
Store strategies in a record/map for easy extension
Add new discount types without modifying calculateDiscount
Use function composition for flexible discount combinations

output_examples.input: My Square class breaks Rectangle expectations when width changes. How do I fix this?
output: Liskov Substitution Principle violation: Square cannot substitute Rectangle
Use composition over inheritance for shape relationships
Define a Shape interface with area calculation
Create separate factory functions for Rectangle and Square
Avoid inheritance when behavioral contracts differ

best_practices: Start with Single Responsibility - split functions by reason to change
Use dependency injection to invert dependencies and improve testability
Prefer composition over inheritance for flexibility
anti_patterns: God classes that handle multiple unrelated responsibilities
Deep inheritance hierarchies that break Liskov substitution
Fat interfaces that force clients to depend on unused methods

faq.question: Which SOLID principle should I learn first?
faq.answer: Start with Single Responsibility. It provides the foundation for clean code and makes other principles easier to apply.

faq.question: Can I apply SOLID principles to existing code?
faq.answer: Yes. Identify violations in critical classes and refactor incrementally. Focus on areas with frequent changes first.

faq.question: Does SOLID apply only to object-oriented code?
faq.answer: While designed for OOP, SOLID concepts translate to functional programming. Focus on maintainability and extensibility.

faq.question: How do I avoid over-engineering with SOLID?
faq.answer: Apply YAGNI. Use SOLID when you need actual flexibility, not for hypothetical future requirements.

faq.question: What is the relationship between SOLID and design patterns?
faq.answer: SOLID principles guide design decisions. Patterns like Strategy, Factory, and Repository help implement these principles.

faq.question: Can I use SOLID with TypeScript?
faq.answer: Absolutely. TypeScript interfaces and type system support SOLID principles well. This skill uses TypeScript examples.
